title: Why should we worry about sustainability?
displayTitle: Why should we worry about sustainability?
body:
Open data needs to remain relevant, up to date and accessible to be useful. Together, these three qualities make up the sustainability of a dataset

A sustainable programme is one that continues to regularly release data with maintained or improving quality and quantity

For something to be sustainable it is ‘able to be maintained at a certain rate or level’

For an open data release to be sustainable, it must maintain regular updates with at least the same level of quality and quantity.

In this module we'll look at:
  • How to make sense of sustainability
  • Why sustainability matters to you
  • What tell-tale signs to look for in open datasets

title: All about open data sustainability – in two minutes
displayTitle: All about open data sustainability – in two minutes
body: The ODI’s Ulrich Atz explains the importance of sustainability in open data, why the concept matters to users and talks through some of the key indicators that an open data release is built to last

title: Making sense of sustainability in open data
displayTitle: Making sense of sustainability in open data
body: What do we mean by the term ‘sustainability’ and how does it relate to open data sources?

_items.title: What does the term mean?
_items.body: For something to be sustainable it is ‘able to be maintained at a certain rate or level’. For an open data release to be sustainable, it must maintain regular updates with at least the same level of quality and quantity.

_items.title: What influences sustainability?
_items.body:
A sustainable open dataset always has three things behind it:
  • Secure funding to cover the cost of updates
  • Active support of publishers to prioritise updates
  • Wide reuse by other people to demonstrate the value

_items.title: What about an example?
_items.body: Transport for London maintain more than 30 open data feeds with a commitment in their digital strategy to regularly update. TfL feeds are used by more than 5000 developers creating applications that reach millions of users and give TfL a clear incentive to keep the data up to date: http://bit.ly/1hpC4Mx

title: Why does sustainability matter?
body: Why should I care about whether the open data I work with is sustainable?

_items.title: Solid foundations
_items.body: A sustainable source of data is a well-laid foundation: you can build on it with confidence because you know it will still be around in the future. If your data isn’t sustainable, are you ready to risk your idea on a shaky foundation?

_items.title: Useful for users
_items.body: No-one stays up-to-date using last year’s newspaper. When you are finding open data, you want the latest version. Recognising sustainable datasets gives you the confidence you are working from current information

_items.title: Better for business
_items.body: As a business using open data, you are investing in an idea you hope will pay off in future. Un-sustainable data can vanish overnight and leave a business without a product. The more sustainable the data on which you based your idea, the less risk of your investment not paying off

_items.title: Perfect for publishers
_items.body: Sustainable open data releases are more popular with users. As a publisher of open data, the goal is to get as many people as possible creating value which is best done by sustaining your release

title: Looking for clues
body: A sustainable release combines secure funding, active support and  wide reuse. These traits are not always obvious when you first find a dataset. Ask yourself the following to help spot good sources:

_items.title: What is the source?
_items.body: Ask yourself who has released the data and how much confidence do you have in their commitment to continue updating it? One of the most important indicators of sustainability is how confident you feel in the organisation who collects it. If the data is from government, might an election or a change in priority affect the release?

_items.title: Who is funding the release?
_items.body: Even though open data is free to access, use and share, there is still a cost in creating, maintaining and publishing usable data. Ask yourself how that dataset has been paid for and how confident you are about that funding being continued. If government funded, think about where else the dataset is used? Is it the result of a mandate or used in other processes/ places? If the dataset is used elsewhere it is quite likely that the data will continue to be used If drawn from the private sector, think about why the company, charity or person is releasing the data? Is this something they fund themselves, the result of an existing process or a dedicated programme? The more other reasons why the publisher needs that data, the more likely they will continue to release it

_items.title: What does the license say?
_items.body: Remember that without a license, data is not truly open. The licence gives you certainty that data can be used and shared for a wide range of purposes. Licenses also give you a clue as to how the publisher of a dataset looks at the sustainability. When looking at a license, ask yourself what does the text say about the future of the dataset? Does it contain a commitment to update regularly? Is there an ‘expiry date’ for the data included? Licenses usually tell you something about the publisher’s confidence in the sustainability of the dataset

_items.alt: Who is already using the data?
_items.title: Who is already using the data?
_items.body: The more people are already using a dataset, the more likely the publisher is to regularly update the release to meet their demand. Remember that there is little point in putting data into the public domain if there is no one prepared or incentivised to use and create new value from it. Ask yourself who else seems to be creating things with this dataset? If other people are creating great success stories with the data, the publisher has a compelling reason to sustain the release. For example, TFL has a community of more than 5000 developers who are turning their open data into real value for the company. This use makes TfL’s data one of the most sustainable examples available because the company has a clear reason to provide secure funding and active support in response to the wide reuse

_items.title: What is the publishing history?
_items.body: Sustainability is ultimately about how much trust you place in the publisher. One of the best ways to make up your mind about how someone will behave in the future is to look at how they have behaved in the past. For an open dataset, past behaviour can be found in the publishing history. Ask yourself how long the dataset has been published for? A long history of updates is a good sign because it demonstrates that the publisher has a proven commitment to regular, quality updates

_items.alt: How can I use this data?
_items.title: Who is already using the data?
_items.body: A final question to ask yourself is what can I do to make the dataset more sustainable? One of the biggest causes of dataset updates being neglected is that no one is using it. Even one user can make a real difference to the sustainability of a dataset if they are able to show how they have used it to create value. Ask yourself how you can create a story around the dataset to show its value to the publisher and demonstrate a clear case for sustaining the release

title: Are you ready?
body: Which of these does not influence the sustainability of an open dataset
instruction: Select one of the options below and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That's it! - The size of the file is not a factor in sustainability. What matters most are a secure source of funding, the active support of the publisher and wide reuse to generate value from the data

title: Summary
body:
In this module, we have examined how you, as an open data user, can better judge the reliability and longevity of a particulr open data release. We have learned that a sustainable open data release combines a long-term commitment.

What you have learned
  • What influences the sustainability of a dataset
  • Why sustainability matters to you
  • How to spot tell-tale signs of sustainability
